item.title: List of UFO religions
item.description:
UFO Religions ðŸ”—

UFO religions are groups that incorporate beliefs about communication with extraterrestrial beings into their religious doctrines. These groups often interpret major religions as being based on supernatural beings from heaven. Communication methods include telepathy and astral projection. A common belief is that humanity can be saved through education provided by aliens, leading to societal improvement. Alien abduction experiences can also contribute to the formation of these religions.

Background ðŸ”—

This section provides context for understanding UFO religions. It highlights that these religions generally involve belief in communication with extraterrestrial beings, often through physical contact, telepathy, or astral projection. These groups typically believe that aliens will save humanity by teaching them a better way to live, sometimes by taking believers to a more positive location. UFO religions emphasize spiritual growth and the evolution of humanity.

J. Gordon Melton is identified as considering the “I AM” Activity, founded by Guy Ballard, as the first UFO religion. However, Christopher Hugh Partridge views it as a theosophical religion rather than a UFO religion. Partridge emphasizes the belief within UFO religions that supreme beings originate from other planets or planes, not from Earth.

The Roswell incident of 1947 is identified as a key event in the history of UFO spirituality, marking the emergence of UFOs into public consciousness. UFO religion is placed within the context of theosophical esotericism and New Age thought, with many groups believing that extraterrestrial beings are heralds of a new era.

The Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, is described as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults. Heaven’s Gate and the Order of the Solar Temple are mentioned as controversial groups combining UFO beliefs with contactee assertions. Scientology is also discussed as a UFO religion due to its Xenu cosmogony and space opera elements.

List ðŸ”—

This section provides a table listing various UFO religions, their founders, and the year they were founded. The list includes:

  • Aetherius Society: Founded by George King in 1955.
  • Ashtar Galactic Command: Founded by Thelma B. Terrill (“Tuella”) in 1977.
  • CEIRUS: Founded by Jean MiguÃ¨res in 1987.
  • Chen Tao: Founded by Hon-ming Chen in 1993.
  • Christ Brotherhood: Founded by Wallace C. Halsey in 1956.
  • Cosmic Circle of Fellowship: Founded by William R. Ferguson in 1955.
  • Fiat Lux: Founded by Uriella in 1980.
  • Freie Interessengemeinschaft fÃ¼r Grenz- und Geisteswissenschaften und Ufologiestudien: Founded by Billy Meier in the 1970s.
  • Ground Crew Project: Founded by Sheldon Nidle in the 1980s.
  • Heaven’s Gate: Founded by Marshall Applewhite and Bonnie Nettles in the 1970s.
  • “I AM” Activity: Founded by Guy Ballard in the 1930s.
  • Industrial Church of the New World Comforter: Founded by Allen Michael in 1973.
  • Mark-Age: Founded by Charles Boyd Gentzel and Pauline Sharpe in 1962.
  • Nation of Islam: Founded by Wallace Fard Muhammad in 1930.
  • NÃ©o-Phare: Founded by Arnaud Mussy in 2001.
  • Nuwaubian Nation: Founded by Dwight York in the 1970s.
  • Order of the Solar Temple: Founded by Joseph Di Mambro and Luc Jouret in 1984.
  • RaÃ«lism: Founded by RaÃ«l in 1974.
  • Rational Culture: Founded by Manoel Jacintho Coelho in the 1930s.
  • Sanctuary of Thought: Founded by Truman Bethurum in the 1950s.
  • The Seekers: Founded by Charles Laughead (aka “Dr. Armstrong”) or Dorothy Martin (aka “Marian Keech”) in 1953.
  • Siderella: Founded by Jean-Paul Appel-GuÃ©ry.
  • Scientology: Founded by L. Ron Hubbard in 1952.
  • Unarius: Founded by Ernest Norman and Ruth Norman in 1954.
  • Universe People: Founded by Ivo A. Benda in 1997.
  • Urantia movement: Authorship of The Urantia Book is unknown and disputed. The book alleges it was written by celestial beings. Founded between 1924 and 1955.
  • Vale do Amanhecer: Founded by Neiva Chaves Zelaya in the 1960s.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics and links for further exploration, including:

  • Religion portal
  • Outer space portal
  • Doomsday cult
  • List of new religious movements
  • List of ufologists
  • List of UFO organizations

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_UFO_religions

item.title: Ground Crew Project
item.description:
Ground Crew Project ðŸ”—

The Ground Crew Project is a UFO religion originating in the United States, founded in the 1980s by Sheldan Nidle. It transitioned online in 1996 and later divided into the “Ground Crew” and “Planetary Activation Organisation.” The group anticipates a cosmic transformation of Earth, facilitated by a passage through a ‘photon belt’ and aided by the “Galactic Federation.” Members prepare for first contact, envisioning themselves as intermediaries between extraterrestrials and humanity. Despite failed predictions, the group maintains its belief in imminent contact and the need to elevate mankind’s consciousness.

Sheldan Nidle ðŸ”—

Sheldan Nidle, born in 1946, claims to have had extraterrestrial encounters from a young age, including telepathic communication and learning aboard spacecraft with ETs from Sirius. He published Youâ€™re Becoming a Galactic Human in 1994, detailing a childhood encounter. He claims regular communication with ETs since 1955, which he ceased at age 14 to fulfill his ‘star seed’ mission. He later became involved with the Amateur Astronomers Club and a film about Nikola Tesla. Nidle holds advanced degrees from Ohio University and the University of Southern California. In the mid-1980s, he resumed contact with the “Galactic Federation” and became a lecturer representing them.

Galactic Federation ðŸ”—

The Galactic Federation is described as an alliance of extraterrestrial civilizations within the Milky Way galaxy. This concept is popular in UFO religions and New Age movements.

Haim Eshed’s claims ðŸ”—

In 2020, Haim Eshed, former head of Israel’s military space program, claimed that aliens have contacted representatives of the United States and Israel, but humanity is not ready for contact. He stated that aliens are present on Earth and have formed a “Galactic Federation” to avoid mass hysteria until humanity is ready. NASA responded by stating that no extraterrestrial life has been found, but the search continues.

Photon Belt ðŸ”—

Beginning in 1996, Nidle channeled messages about an imminent apocalypse due to Earth’s planetary transformation. He claimed to lead a mission for the “Galactic Federation of Planets” to prepare the world for this transformation as the planet passes into a cosmic ‘photon belt’. This area of space supposedly has high energy properties that would transform Earth into a pristine state and restore superhuman abilities by altering human DNA to a 12-helix pattern. The pineal gland would be activated, and humans would regain cosmic abilities like rejuvenation, telepathy, and overcoming illness. The channeling claimed that human structures would be destroyed, and the only safe places would be underground or in spaceships.

Imminent Landing ðŸ”—

The narrative stated that a mass landing of 15 million starships of the “Galactic Federation” would occur no later than December 17, 1996, to raise humanity’s consciousness using advanced technology, achieving a galactic and divine society by 2012. The landing would involve advanced races like Pleiadians, Sirians, Cassopeans, and Arcturians, who would meet and placate human populations. Earthly weapons would be neutralized, mechanical devices shut down, and world government taken over by the Spiritual Hierarchy. The Earth transformation would include telepathy, airborne transport, and photon energy generators. This is considered a “cargoistic” belief, where alien “cargo” brings about human ascension.

Ground Crew ðŸ”—

The “Ground Crew” refers to the virtual congregation who join the mission. Members were told they would assist humanity and the extraterrestrials as councillors and ambassadors. They would be trained by space forces and receive implants. After failed predictions, the emphasis shifted to spiritual development, requiring the Ground Crew to help raise humanity spiritually and assist in ecological restoration. This involved gathering humanity through world meditation days to harmonize vibrations and creating a ’network of light’ with other new age groups.

Landings delayed ðŸ”—

The December 1996 mass landing did not occur, but Nidle continued to spread messages that spaceships would appear soon. Further dates, including the Gregorian New Year and spring of 1997, also passed without a landing. Delays were attributed to a solar storm and planetary instability. Details about the comet Hale-Bopp were communicated, and the number of spaceships in the landing fleet was increased to 25 million.

Hale-Bopp ðŸ”—

A new landing date was set to coincide with the arrival of the Hale-Bopp comet on May 5, 1997. The comet was described as a large spaceship with cloaking and holographic systems, containing a crew of over 200,000 beings and 10,000 ambassadors. This would coincide with the mass landing by the Federation. After the mass suicide of Heaven’s Gate members, the Ground Crew distanced themselves from such acts. Instead of a mass landing, a meeting between a shuttle from the comet and a shuttle from the “Galactic Federation Fleet” took place near Ayers Rock in Australia, where a ceremony was conducted, and papers were exchanged.

Further re-scheduling and shift in focus ðŸ”—

Nidle and the Ground Crew blamed repeated failed prophecies on external factors, such as dark forces conspiring with ‘planetary elites’. Messages began to deny the relevance of specific arrival dates and talked about “the right divine time.” The focus shifted to humans assisting in the planet’s transformation before galactic intervention. Salvation became a two-way street, determined by human attitudes. A more spiritual content appeared, referring to beings like Ashtar Sheran, Aaron Alaje, Megha Alcorn, Merku Alcorn, Great White Brotherhood, Ascended Masters, and archangels.

Split ðŸ”—

In December 1997, Nidle split with Valerie Donnell, his secretary and the Ground Crew’s chief administrator. Donnell retained the Ground Crew name and website, posting channeled messages with a UFO content focused on personal spiritual transformation from a new age perspective. Nidle founded the Planetary Activation Organisation, restructuring it as the only source for messages about the Galactic Federation. He established a hierarchical system and created a “Web of Light” to unite like-minded groups.

Evolution of the narrative ðŸ”—

According to Nidle’s channeling, the Federation remained dedicated to first contact, but the spiritual transformation of humans became the main focus. Earth rulers were identified as a secret cabal, but would be removed by the Federation. ‘Star Gates’ were being placed in the upper atmosphere, and ‘Galactic and Medical Teams’ were assisting people during sleep. Earth was portrayed as a vitally important planet due to humanity’s exalted role, acting as a switch in the spiritual transformation of the Milky Way. By 2000, the movement continued to develop its membership base, claiming hundreds of Planetary Activation Groups in over 29 countries. The Planetary Activation Organisation is classified as a progressive millennialist group promising collective salvation and a terrestrial paradise.

Credibility ðŸ”—

The Ground Crew employed strategies to avoid prophetic disconfirmation and cognitive dissonance, such as disclaimers and exploiting temporality. Nidle reconceptualized the movement through spiritualization, changing the focus from a UFO landing to the need for humans to raise their own spirituality. Due to the virtual nature of the group, it is impossible to accurately account for membership. The movement’s period of failed prophecy is no longer online. The online narrative functions like fiction, conveying a vivid imaginary world and apocalyptic expectancy.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_Federation_(ufology)

item.title: UFO religion
item.description:
UFO Religion ðŸ”—

A UFO religion is a religion where belief in extraterrestrial entities operating unidentified flying objects (UFOs) is a core element. Adherents typically believe these ETs are interested in humanity’s welfare and that humanity will eventually join an existing ET civilization. Some UFO religions incorporate ETs into a supernatural worldview, blurring the lines between aliens and angels. These religions draw inspiration from early science fiction, ufology, UFO sightings, and alien abduction stories. The Aetherius Society, founded by George King, is considered the first UFO religion.

Summary ðŸ”—

Adherents believe that the arrival or rediscovery of alien civilizations, technologies, and spirituality will enable humans to overcome ecological, spiritual, and social problems. Issues like hatred, war, bigotry, and poverty are believed to be resolvable through superior alien technology and spiritual abilities. These belief systems are often millenarian in their outlook.

UFO religions developed in countries like the United States, Canada, France, the United Kingdom, and Japan, where technology is advanced enough to conceive of ETs and where religion is not suppressed. The term “flying saucers” and the popular notion of the UFO originated in 1947. The study of UFO religions by sociologists, historians, theologians, scholars of religious studies, and new religious movements began in the 1950s.

Notable UFO Religions ðŸ”—

UFO religions generally involve belief in communication with extraterrestrial beings through physical contact, telepathy, and astral projection. These groups often believe that humanity will be saved by aliens who will educate humans on a better way to live or take believers to a more positive location. Extraterrestrial beings are often seen pleading with humanity to improve itself and move away from greed and violence. UFO religions emphasize spiritual growth and the evolution of humanity. A UFO religion can form before or after an individual claims to have experienced an alien abduction.

J. Gordon Melton identifies the “I AM” Activity, founded by Guy Ballard, as the first UFO religion, although Christopher Hugh Partridge views it as a theosophical religion. Partridge notes that UFO religions believe the supreme being or “evolved entity” came from another plane or planet. The 1947 Roswell incident is a key point in time within UFO spirituality. James R. Lewis notes that Ufologists see it as the date of the “emergence of UFOs into the public consciousness.” Partridge places UFO religion within the context of theosophical esotericism and asserts that it began to be associated as “UFO religion” after the Roswell incident. He notes that most UFO religions still have many of the key points associated with Theosophy, such as belief in the same Spiritual Hierarchy, and he also draws parallels to New Age thought.

Stephen Hunt describes the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as “probably the first and certainly the most enduring UFO cult.” Hunt places the Aetherius Society and RaÃ«lism among the “most renowned” of the “flying saucer cults.” Melodie Campbell and Stephen A. Kent place the Aetherius Society and Unarius as among the “oldest and most studied” of the flying saucer cults. They describe Heaven’s Gate and Order of the Solar Temple as the “most controversial groups combining UFO belief with variations of contactee assertions.” Gregory L. Reece classes Scientology as a “UFO group,” discussing elements of the Xenu cosmogony and Space opera in Scientology doctrine. He compares Scientology to the Aetherius Society and Ashtar Command. Victoria Nelson writes that “[t]he most prominent current UFO religion is probably the science fiction writer L. Ron Hubbard’s Church of Scientology.”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_religion
